Line 236: Line 236:
===5 April===
===5 April===
â
On 5 April [[Physicians for Human Rights]] reported that a number of doctors have gone missing at the Salmaniya Medical Complex in the Bahraini capital Manama following recent interrogations by security forces.<ref>[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/]</ref> <ref>[http://physiciansforhumanrights.org/library/news-2011-04-05.html]</ref>
+
On 5 April [[Physicians for Human Rights]] reported that a number of doctors have gone missing at the Salmaniya Medical Complex in the Bahraini capital Manama following recent interrogations by security forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/ |title=Babylon & Beyond | BAHRAIN: Fourth person dies in police custody as human rights groups allege torture | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://physiciansforhumanrights.org/library/news-2011-04-05.html |title=PHR Reports Disappearances of at Least Two Bahraini Doctors in Past 24 Hours |publisher=Physiciansforhumanrights.org |date=2011-04-05 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
===7 April===
===7 April===
â
On 7 April [[MÃ©decins Sans FrontiÃ¨res|Docters Without Borders]] released a report stating that hospitals in Bahrain were used as bait by the government to snare wounded pro-democracy protestors after security forces took over health facilities. The Bahraini government, however, denies these claims.<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jEbzfg0NYmpGm2PsexchJJ3wlMuQ?docId=CNG.6f1a3c295003e2f3af5b879590880652.281 AFP: Bahrain hospitals used as 'bait' in crackdown: MSF]. Google.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-09.</ref> On the same day 4 players of the [[Bahrain national football team]] were suspended after being accused of lending their support to anti-government protests. [[A'ala Hubail]] and [[Mohammed Hubail]] are reported to have been arrested during a training session with [[Al Ahli]] after being identified on television at a rally to protest against the Bahrain government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/903928/bahrain-players-banned-for-role-in-protests?cc=5739|title=Bahrain players banned|publisher=ESPN}}</ref>
+
On 7 April [[MÃ©decins Sans FrontiÃ¨res|Docters Without Borders]] released a report stating that hospitals in Bahrain were used as bait by the government to snare wounded pro-democracy protestors after security forces took over health facilities. The Bahraini government, however, denies these claims.<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jEbzfg0NYmpGm2PsexchJJ3wlMuQ?docId=CNG.6f1a3c295003e2f3af5b879590880652.281 AFP: Bahrain hospitals used as 'bait' in crackdown: MSF]. Google.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-09.</ref> On the same day 4 players of the [[Bahrain national football team]] were suspended after being accused of lending their support to anti-government protests. [[A'ala Hubail]] and [[Mohammed Hubail]] are reported to have been arrested during a training session with [[Al Ahli]] after being identified on television at a rally to protest against the Bahrain government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/903928/bahrain-players-banned-for-role-in-protests?cc=5739|title=Bahrain players banned|publisher=ESPN}}</ref>
===9 April===
===9 April===
â
On 9 April 20 masked men stormed the house of the daughter of leading Shia activist Abdulhadi al-Khawaja. During this raid, Abdulhadi al-Khawaja was seized in the middle of the night and taken away with his two sons-in-law.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13023428|title=Leading Bahrain activist Abdulhadi al-Khawaja arrested|author=Frank Gardner|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
+
On 9 April 20 masked men stormed the house of the daughter of leading Shia activist Abdulhadi al-Khawaja. During this raid, Abdulhadi al-Khawaja was seized in the middle of the night and taken away with his two sons-in-law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13023428|title=Leading Bahrain activist Abdulhadi al-Khawaja arrested|author=Frank Gardner|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
===10 April===
===10 April===
â
On 10 April the interior ministry reported that two Shia activists died in custody.<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i2i4lh_L_8FAGOMbJ6wBWVqO_MgQ?docId=CNG.2083dc8d5459a36e02d29714e6147b9d.891]</ref>
+
On 10 April the interior ministry reported that two Shia activists died in custody.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 3 days ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i2i4lh_L_8FAGOMbJ6wBWVqO_MgQ?docId=CNG.2083dc8d5459a36e02d29714e6147b9d.891 |title=AFP: Two Shiite activists die in Bahraini custody |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
===11 April===
===11 April===
â
Four [[CNN]] reporters were arrested by Bahraini security forces in the village of Bani Jamrah for filming in unrestricted areas ,they were released later on . <ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/04/11/bahrain.detain/index.html]</ref>
+
Four [[CNN]] reporters were arrested by Bahraini security forces in the village of Bani Jamrah for filming in unrestricted areas ,they were released later on . <ref>{{cite web|author=ByÂ  Scott Bronstein, Amber Lyon and Taryn Fixel, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/04/11/bahrain.detain/index.html |title=CNN arrests expose crackdown in Bahrain - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
===12 April===
===12 April===
â
One Bahraini national and two Iranian nationals were accused by the Bahraini High Court of providing military and economic information to the Iranian [[Revolutionary Guards]] between 2002 and April 2010, with "the intention of harming the national interests of the country". The court has adjourned the case until April 20.<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hO_MeSIHVIgnsA-JKH49lxIGhFWw?docId=CNG.10d3a9e29c2cbf7d2da3ebd746b3a9f1.2a1]</ref>
+
One Bahraini national and two Iranian nationals were accused by the Bahraini High Court of providing military and economic information to the Iranian [[Revolutionary Guards]] between 2002 and April 2010, with "the intention of harming the national interests of the country". The court has adjourned the case until April 20.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 2 days ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hO_MeSIHVIgnsA-JKH49lxIGhFWw?docId=CNG.10d3a9e29c2cbf7d2da3ebd746b3a9f1.2a1 |title=AFP: Bahrain tries three for spying for Iran |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
â
Iranian member of parliament Ruhollah Hosseinian said that the Islamic Republic should dispatch its military forces to Bahrain.<ref>[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7347283.html]</ref> <ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/174197.html]</ref>
+
Iranian member of parliament Ruhollah Hosseinian said that the Islamic Republic should dispatch its military forces to Bahrain.<ref>{{cite web|author=161 |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7347283.html |title=Iran's MP asks for military dispatch to Bahrain: TV website - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.peopledaily.com.cn |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/174197.html |title=PressTV - Iran MP offers military use in Bahrain |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
â
The daughter of prominent activist Abdulhadi al-Khawaja, Zainab al-Khawaja, announced on her blog, as well as on Twitter, in a letter addressed to President Barack Obama that she will not eat until her father is released, along with her husband, brother-in-law and uncle.<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gS3X_kHwr00czIr0baHF3tSnxXRg?docId=6540395]</ref>
+
The daughter of prominent activist Abdulhadi al-Khawaja, Zainab al-Khawaja, announced on her blog, as well as on Twitter, in a letter addressed to President Barack Obama that she will not eat until her father is released, along with her husband, brother-in-law and uncle.<ref>{{cite web|last=Surk |first=Barbara |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gS3X_kHwr00czIr0baHF3tSnxXRg?docId=6540395 |title=The Canadian Press: Daughter of jailed Bahrain human rights activist says she's on hunger strike until his release |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-04-10 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
â
Release of 86 prisoners and suspension of more teachers and doctors was reported by Al Wasat Newspaper on 12/4/2011, Issue No. 3139.<ref>http://www.alwasatnews.com/3139/news/read/536859/1.html</ref>
+
Release of 86 prisoners and suspension of more teachers and doctors was reported by Al Wasat Newspaper on 12/4/2011, Issue No. 3139.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3139/news/read/536859/1.html |title=Ø§ÙØ¥ÙØ±Ø§Ø¬ Ø¹Ù 86 ÙÙÙÙÙØ§Ù ÙØ¥ÙÙØ§Ù Ø¢Ø®Ø±ÙÙ | ÙØ­ÙÙØ§Øª - ØµØ­ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙÙØ³Ø· Ø§ÙØ¨Ø­Ø±ÙÙÙØ© - ÙÙÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¨Ø­Ø±ÙÙ |publisher=Alwasatnews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
==Censorship and repression==
==Censorship and repression==
Line 276: Line 276:
;Deaths
;Deaths
â
Bahrain's Interior Minister, Sheikh Rashed bin Abdullah al-Khalifa, stated on 29 March that a total of twenty-four people had been killed in the protests. He said that four security officers, seven civilians and 13 protesters had perished in the weeks of unrest.<ref name="arabianbusiness.com"/> Two of the civilians were an Indian and a Bangladeshi. With the deaths of four detained protestors in custody between 3 and 12 April<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/201141220154357546.html Bahrain opposition figure 'dies in custody'] Retrieved on 2011-04-13.</ref> the death toll reached 30 (when including the four police officers and one Saudi soldier killed<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/bahrain-state-of-emergency-saudi-soldier-killed_n_835832.html|title=Bahrain Declares State Of Emergency After Saudi Soldier Shot Dead|publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref>).<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hjkBtBjjzr0PdgHCKrnX2R4CnldQ?docId=CNG.34b89149aa6e7d06680c9cf785978729.671 AFP: Bahrain activist dies in jail: ministry]. Google.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-05.</ref> The list of killed civilians and one Saudi soldier is as follows:
+
Bahrain's Interior Minister, Sheikh Rashed bin Abdullah al-Khalifa, stated on 29 March that a total of twenty-four people had been killed in the protests. He said that four security officers, seven civilians and 13 protesters had perished in the weeks of unrest.<ref name="arabianbusiness.com"/> Two of the civilians were an Indian and a Bangladeshi. With the deaths of four detained protestors in custody between 3 and 12 April<ref name="aljazeera1"/> the death toll reached 30 (when including the four police officers and one Saudi soldier killed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/bahrain-state-of-emergency-saudi-soldier-killed_n_835832.html|title=Bahrain Declares State Of Emergency After Saudi Soldier Shot Dead|publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref>).<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hjkBtBjjzr0PdgHCKrnX2R4CnldQ?docId=CNG.34b89149aa6e7d06680c9cf785978729.671 AFP: Bahrain activist dies in jail: ministry]. Google.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-05.</ref> The list of killed civilians and one Saudi soldier is as follows:

Line 473: Line 473:
On 26 March 2011 [[Shiites]] of [[Mumbai]] held a protest rally after the Friday Prayers also joined by some [[Bahraini]] students studying in India to condemn the "oppressive regimes" in Bahrain and Yemen and their use of force against peaceful citizens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2011/mar/250311-news-pune-Bahraini-students-Mumbai-to-condemn-military.htm |title=We want to go back to be with our families |publisher=[[Mid-Day]] |date= 25 March 2011 |accessdate= 26 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/article1572745.ece |title=Protest Held Against Brutalities in Bahrain |work = [[The Hindu]] |date= 26 March 2011 |accessdate= 26 March 2011}}</ref>
On 26 March 2011 [[Shiites]] of [[Mumbai]] held a protest rally after the Friday Prayers also joined by some [[Bahraini]] students studying in India to condemn the "oppressive regimes" in Bahrain and Yemen and their use of force against peaceful citizens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2011/mar/250311-news-pune-Bahraini-students-Mumbai-to-condemn-military.htm |title=We want to go back to be with our families |publisher=[[Mid-Day]] |date= 25 March 2011 |accessdate= 26 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/article1572745.ece |title=Protest Held Against Brutalities in Bahrain |work = [[The Hindu]] |date= 26 March 2011 |accessdate= 26 March 2011}}</ref>
â
{{flag|Iran}} â President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] said of the invasion by foreign forces that "this expedition is a very foul and doomed experience, and regional nations will hold the American government responsible for this"<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net"/> and that "Today, we witness the degree of pressure imposed on the majority of people in Bahrain. What has happened is bad, unjustifiable and irreparable."<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0316/breaking3.html "Iran condemns Bahraini assault"].</ref> Foreign Minister [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] discussed the crisis with the UN and Arab League chiefs. He also expressed worry over the use of violence against a "peaceful movement,"<ref>{{cite web|author=BaniComm Co. |url=http://www.isna.ir/ISNA/NewsView.aspx?ID=News-1735952&Lang=E |title=Iran FM discusses Bahrain crisis with UN, AL chiefs|publisher=Isna.ir |accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> while Iran also objected to the presence of foreign troops in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kgmi.com/Iran-objects-to-foreign-troops-in-Bahrain/9402346 |title=Iran Objects To Foreign Troops In Bahrain â KGMI-AM |publisher=Kgmi.com |date=6 January 2009 |accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> Bahrain recalled its ambassador from Iran for "consultations."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=301887 |title=Local News " Bahrain Recalls Envoy to Iran |publisher= [[Gulf Daily News]] |date= 9 March 2009 |accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> Iran also followed suit citing the crackdown on the mostly Shia crowd. As well as denouncing the deployment of the Saudi-led force of Gulf Arab states, seen as propping up the Sunni monarchy, Iran complained to the [[United Nations]] about the crackdown while also asking regional states to urge Saudi Arabia to withdraw its troops.<ref name="blog17march"/> On 19 March a group of Iranian protestors stoned the Saudi consulate in the northeastern city of Mashhad to protest against the killing of Shiites in Bahrain<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110319-iran-protesters-stone-saudi-consulate-report|title=Iran protesters stone Saudi consulate : report|publisher=France24}}</ref> On 20 March Iran summoned Bahrain's [[charge d'affaires]] and ordered the explusion of one Bahraini diplomat.<ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/03/20/Iran-escalates-diplomatic-row-with-Bahrain/UPI-81421300644104/ Iran escalates diplomatic row with Bahrain]. UPI.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-09.</ref>
+
{{flag|Iran}} â President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] said of the invasion by foreign forces that "this expedition is a very foul and doomed experience, and regional nations will hold the American government responsible for this"<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net"/> and that "Today, we witness the degree of pressure imposed on the majority of people in Bahrain. What has happened is bad, unjustifiable and irreparable."<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0316/breaking3.html "Iran condemns Bahraini assault"].</ref> Foreign Minister [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] discussed the crisis with the UN and Arab League chiefs. He also expressed worry over the use of violence against a "peaceful movement,"<ref>{{cite web|author=BaniComm Co. |url=http://www.isna.ir/ISNA/NewsView.aspx?ID=News-1735952&Lang=E |title=Iran FM discusses Bahrain crisis with UN, AL chiefs|publisher=Isna.ir |accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> while Iran also objected to the presence of foreign troops in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kgmi.com/Iran-objects-to-foreign-troops-in-Bahrain/9402346 |title=Iran Objects To Foreign Troops In Bahrain â KGMI-AM |publisher=Kgmi.com |date=6 January 2009 |accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> Bahrain recalled its ambassador from Iran for "consultations."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=301887 |title=Local News " Bahrain Recalls Envoy to Iran |publisher= [[Gulf Daily News]] |date= 9 March 2009 |accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> Iran also followed suit citing the crackdown on the mostly Shia crowd. As well as denouncing the deployment of the Saudi-led force of Gulf Arab states, seen as propping up the Sunni monarchy, Iran complained to the [[United Nations]] about the crackdown while also asking regional states to urge Saudi Arabia to withdraw its troops.<ref name="blog17march"/> On 19 March a group of Iranian protestors stoned the Saudi consulate in the northeastern city of Mashhad to protest against the killing of Shiites in Bahrain<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110319-iran-protesters-stone-saudi-consulate-report|title=Iran protesters stone Saudi consulate : report|publisher=France24}}</ref> On 20 March Iran summoned Bahrain's [[charge d'affaires]] and ordered the explusion of one Bahraini diplomat.<ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/03/20/Iran-escalates-diplomatic-row-with-Bahrain/UPI-81421300644104/ Iran escalates diplomatic row with Bahrain]. UPI.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-09.</ref>
{{flag|Iraq}} â Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated that he was "worried that the intervention of foreign forces will complicate the issues instead of solving them" <ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/17/3166047.htm?section=justin |title=Shiites Rally Behind Bahrain Protesters |publisher=ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> Grand Ayatollah [[Ali al-Sistani]], who is based in the Iraqi city of Najaf, "appealed to Bahraini authorities to stop violence against unarmed citizens," his spokesman, Hamad al-Khaffaf, said.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Moqtada al-Sadr]] called for protests in [[Baghdad]] and [[Basra]] on 16 March to "support the Bahraini people and to denounce and condemn the murdering of innocent revolutionaries. We want to show solidarity with our brothers in Bahrain. The killing of innocents should stop."<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net"/>
{{flag|Iraq}} â Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated that he was "worried that the intervention of foreign forces will complicate the issues instead of solving them" <ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/17/3166047.htm?section=justin |title=Shiites Rally Behind Bahrain Protesters |publisher=ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate= 16 March 2011}}</ref> Grand Ayatollah [[Ali al-Sistani]], who is based in the Iraqi city of Najaf, "appealed to Bahraini authorities to stop violence against unarmed citizens," his spokesman, Hamad al-Khaffaf, said.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Moqtada al-Sadr]] called for protests in [[Baghdad]] and [[Basra]] on 16 March to "support the Bahraini people and to denounce and condemn the murdering of innocent revolutionaries. We want to show solidarity with our brothers in Bahrain. The killing of innocents should stop."<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net"/>

Al Wasat Newspaper the only opposition paper in Bahrain reported on Tuesday, 12th April 2011 Issue no. 3139 that 16 Lebanese nationals were requested by the Bahraini Security Authorities to leave the country. No details or reasons for the request were given.<ref>http://www.alwasatnews.com/3139/news/read/536876/1.html</ref>
